data.title: FIRST ALERT: FLASH FLOOD WARNING this morning for Grand Strand
data.meta_description: Debby continues to lift north through North Carolina but could swing occasional downpours our way this evening.
data.text:
MYRTLE BEACH, S.C. (WMBF) - Very heavy rain overnight and early this morning has lead to areas of flooding across the Grand Strand. Additional showers and storms will remain possible today.

FLASH FLOOD WARNING

A FLASH FLOOD WARNING remains in effect for southwestern Brunswick County in southeastern North Carolina, Georgetown County and coastal Horry County until 7:30 AM.

Areas of heavy rain have been falling across the warned area. Between 1 and 3 inches of rain have fallen during the past 3 hours on already saturated grounds. Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are possible. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.

Dangerous flooding from heavy rainfall can be expected, especially

near poor drainage areas and other flood prone locations. It is

harder to recognize flood dangers at night, as it will be difficult

to determine the depth of the water. Roads may be damaged or washed

away. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. If flooding is observed,

then turn around, don`t drown.

FLASH FLOOD WATCH

The FLASH FLOOD WATCH has been extended through the evening. This morning’s rain will ease up by late morning into midday with a round of pop up storms developing this afternoon. With the ground saturated from Debby’s rainfall, additional storms could quickly lead to areas of flash flooding.

THROUGH THE WEEKEND

Debby will continue to pull away from the region on Friday and will be long gone by the weekend. The result will be a gradual return to more typical mid-August weather.

Lingering tropical moisture will maintain a 60% chance of showers and storms at times on Friday between rounds of sunshine. Temperatures will climb into the middle 80s.

The weekend will see rain chances continuing to drop to around 40% on both Saturday and Sunday - pretty typical for this time of the year. Afternoon temperatures on both days will climb into the middle and upper 80s.

RIVER FLOODING

With the recent heavy rainfall, local rivers are already swollen and climbing. The National Weather Service expects flooding to occur on all area rivers, with the Waccamaw River forecast to reach minor flood stage on Friday. Inland rivers may take an extra day or two to crest, hitting the highest levels over the weekend. We have a full breakdown of the river flooding threat here.
